docs.lead_paragraph: Parties Near Agreement On Creating Asbestos Trust Companies, insurers, unions and Democratic and Republican senators are nearing an agreement to end all asbestos lawsuits and instead pay people with asbestos-related diseases from a national, privately financed trust, people who have participated in the talks said. The trust, which would have to be approved by Congress and President Bush, would pay more than $100 billion to hundreds of thousands of asbestos victims over the next 30 years. [Page A1.]

docs.lead_paragraph: The union representing 28,000 apartment building service workers announced early this morning that it had reached a tentative three-year contract with the association of building owners, averting a strike threatened against 3,000 buildings in New York City. After two days of exhausting talks, negotiators for the two sides announced a settlement that calls for wage increases averaging 2.8 percent a year over three years, as well as for increased employer contributions for health care and pensions. At an early morning news conference, Michael Fishman, president of Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union, said, ''We all consider it a fair agreement for the times we live in.''

docs.lead_paragraph: A growing number of pharmaceutical companies are offering to take on prominent public health roles in helping to care for the sickest poor patients in some states. Under the agreements, the drug companies create guidelines for treating Medicaid patients with chronic conditions like asthma and diabetes. The companies then pay for case workers to help patients follow the guidelines -- for example, by phoning them to remind them of the importance of taking their medicine regularly and eating properly. The case workers also talk to the patients' doctors so that care focuses on managing disease rather than treating an acute event like an asthma attack.

headline.main: Drug Makers Expand Their Medicaid Role
